questions.text: An 82-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son because he is concerned about her forgetfulness for the past 2 years. She occasionally walks into a room and forgets why she went there and often forgets where she left her keys. She is sometimes unable to recall a familiar individual's name. She reports that she has become slower at completing sudoku puzzles. She has been living independently since the death of her husband 3 years ago. She goes shopping, cooks her own meals, and plays bridge with her friends every weekend. She is not anxious about her memory lapses. She has no trouble sleeping but has been getting up earlier than she used to. She has hypertension that is managed with hydrochlorothiazide. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows a normal gait. She describes her mood as “good” and her speech is normal. Her thought process is organized and her judgment is intact. She makes one error when performing serial sevens. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mild memory impairment, occasional difficulties in word finding, and slower cognitive processing are normal effects of aging. An important distinguishing factor between normal aging and forms of dementia is the degree to which independence with everyday activities is impaired. In normal aging, independence in daily activities is preserved. Because this patient lives independently and her cognitive exams are within normal limits, dementia is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with Alzheimer disease present with progressive cognitive decline that can manifest with short term memory loss. Often, patients are unaware of their difficulties and relatives may express concern before the patient does. While this patient does have a lack of concern over her memory loss, her daily life is largely unaffected. Moreover, the cognitive dysfunction in Alzheimer disease is often accompanied by behavioral changes (such as aggression, depression, insomnia), which are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudodementia is associated with other psychiatric disorders (especially depression) in which cognitive deficits such as memory loss are seen after the onset of mood symptoms. This patient reports her mood is “good” and the history reveals no symptoms such as anhedonia, changes in appetite, psychomotor agitation, or suicidal ideation that would suggest depression.

D) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) presents with changes in personality and behavior (e.g., apathy), especially inappropriate social behavior in early stages (e.g., disinhibition), which this 82-year-old woman does not show. Additionally, the onset of FTD usually occurs in middle-aged individuals (40–60 years).

E) INCORRECT:

While memory loss is a symptom of Lewy-body dementia, it presents with neurocognitive decline over the course of 8–10 years, beginning with deficits in attention and executive functioning early and memory loss later in the course of disease. Patients may experience visual hallucinations and parkinsonian motor disorders (e.g., shuffling gait, rigidity of movements), which this patient lacks.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with vascular dementia will present with a stepwise decline in cognitive and neurological function causing interference with independence in everyday activities. This patient has a risk factor for cerebrovascular disease (hypertension), but the minor memory loss in this patient is not consistent with the degree of cognitive impairment seen in vascular dementia. Moreover, cognitive impairment is often associated with other focal neurological deficits (e.g., hemiparesis, urinary incontinence, gait disturbance), which are absent in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

The degree of cognitive decline in normal pressure hydrocephalus is generally more severe than the minor memory loss seen in this patient. Normal pressure hydrocephalus presents with the classic triad of “wet, wobbly, and wacky” (urinary incontinence, gait disorder, and dementia), which this patient lacks.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).
questions.hint: These cognitive defects have not interfered with independence in everyday activities of this individual's life.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter for evaluation of progressive cognitive decline and a 1-year history of incontinence. She was diagnosed with Alzheimer disease 5 years ago. The daughter reports that in the past year, her mother has become nonambulatory, can speak only a few intelligible words, and requires assistance with all activities of daily living. Over the past year, she has had decreased appetite and progressive dysphagia, resulting in a 12-kg (26-lb) weight loss. She has been hospitalized three times for aspiration pneumonia, and her diet now consists only of puréed food. She has no advance directives. The daughter says that she does not want her mother to return to the hospital again, but she is concerned about her ability to continue providing care alone. The patient has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. She appears malnourished but well groomed. The patient is oriented only to self. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 0/30, and Functional Assessment Staging Tool scale is 7/7. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of creatinine, urea nitrogen, TSH, and vitamin B12 are within the reference ranges. Her serum albumin concentration is 3 g/dL. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Short-term rehabilitation is generally indicated for patients who require rehabilitation and/or further medical care and who no longer require inpatient care (e.g., a patient treated for pneumonia who is weak from hospitalization but whose infection is cured). This patient's Alzheimer disease is severe, chronic, progressive, and incurable, so rehabilitation would not be beneficial.

B) INCORRECT:

Opioids (e.g., oxycodone) are indicated to treat pain in patients with terminal illness (e.g., bone pain in a patient with metastatic cancer). While this patient has a terminal illness, there is no evidence that she is in pain, so opioids are not indicated.

C) CORRECT:

This nonambulatory patient with severe cognitive impairment, total functional dependence, incontinence, and dysphagia causing frequent aspiration and significant weight loss, has severe end-stage Alzheimer disease. A history of nutritional decline and recurrent hospitalization for aspiration pneumonia indicates a poor prognosis, often with life expectancy measured in months. Hospice care is appropriate when life expectancy is estimated at 6 months or less, and a do-not-resuscitate order is not required. Home hospice provides comfort-focused care and support for caregivers, aligning with both the patient's prognosis and their family's goals and preferences.

The Functional Assessment Staging Tool scale evaluates dementia progression across seven stages of functional decline, with stage 7 indicating very severe dementia.

D) INCORRECT:

Tube feeding in advanced dementia does not improve survival, prevent aspiration pneumonia, or increase quality of life. This approach may increase discomfort, agitation, and risk of complications (e.g., infection, tube dislodgement). Comfort feeding with puréed food, which this patient already receives, is preferred.

E) INCORRECT:

Palliative care focuses on symptom management and quality of life in serious illness, and it can be provided alongside curative treatment at any stage. Inpatient palliative care is reserved for individuals with acute, uncontrolled symptoms (e.g., severe pain, agitation, uncontrolled dyspnea) that cannot be managed outside of a hospital. This patient has no acute symptoms requiring crisis intervention.
questions.hint: Because mortality risk prediction in advanced dementia is difficult, decisions about end-of-life care should include the preferences of the patient and their family.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of concerns about his memory. His wife reports that over the past 7 months he has gradually become more forgetful. He commonly misplaces his car keys and forgets his children's names. He seems to have forgotten how to make dinner and sometimes serves uncooked noodles or raw meat. One night he parked his car in a neighbor's bushes and was found wandering the street. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and COPD. Current medications include atorvastatin, metoprolol, ipratropium, and fluticasone. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is alert and oriented to person and place only. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 19/30. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, creatinine, thyroid-stimulating hormone, liver function tests, vitamin B12 (cobalamin), and folate are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture and subsequent CSF analysis may be helpful in diagnosing specific etiologies of dementia, particularly those of rapid- or early-onset, including meningitis or encephalitis. While this patient exhibits several hallmarks of dementia, his course of development has been relatively slow and subtle. Moreover, his unremarkable vital signs (without evidence of fever or tachycardia), physical examination without neck stiffness or focal neurological deficits, and laboratory findings (without an elevated white blood cell count) decrease suspicion for encephalitis and meningitis as acute causes of dementia for which lumbar puncture would be diagnostically useful.

B) INCORRECT:

Neuropsychologic testing is useful for identifying patients with dementia and in documenting cognitive function over time but has limited utility in differentiating causes of dementia, as there is substantial overlap of the types of deficits involved. Because this patient's clinical history and examination results strongly suggest a diagnosis of dementia, neuropsychologic testing is unlikely to provide additional diagnostic information.


C) INCORRECT:

The ε4 allele of the Apolipoprotein E gene is associated with late-onset Alzheimer disease (AD). A positive genotype test may increase clinical suspicion for AD and help to stratify risk for progression. However, false positives and negatives do occur, and ApoE genotyping is not routinely used in clinical settings. Moreover, while this 72-year-old patient's relatively slow neurocognitive decline and his MMSE score may be consistent with a diagnosis of AD, there are other potential causes of dementia that are also consistent with his clinical course, and a broader diagnostic approach is more appropriate to address this differential.

D) INCORRECT:

Electroencephalography allows characterization of the electrical activity of the cortex and may aid in localizing seizures, which may increase suspicion for structural abnormalities. However, in this older patient with slowly and steadily progressive dementia and without evidence of seizures, EEG is unlikely to aid in identifying the etiology of his condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Functional neuroimaging with a PET scan may reveal distinct patterns that are associated with specific etiologies of dementia (e.g., amyloid CNS lesions, and the presence of localized hypoperfusion in Alzheimer disease or FTD). However, there are numerous other possible etiologies of his neurocognitive decline (e.g., CNS tumor, cerebrovascular disease) that could be detected with other diagnostic studies. PET scans are relatively expensive, provide very specific data, and are not without risk and, as such, would not be appropriate as a first-line imaging modality in this patient with a relatively broad remaining differential.

F) CORRECT:

In patients presenting with new-onset neurocognitive defects, neuroimaging with noncontrast head CT or MRI helps exclude pathologies such as CNS tumors, subdural hematoma, or normal pressure hydrocephalus. Specific atrophy or lesion patterns may be associated with particular etiologies, e.g., multiple lacunar infarcts in vascular dementia (VD) or reduced hippocampal volume in Alzheimer disease (AD). In older adults with a slow, insidious onset of dementia and only cognitive deficits, such as this patient, AD and VD are among the most common causes of dementia, and MRI findings may help guide the next steps in management.
questions.hint: This patient has several signs of dementia including forgetfulness, impaired judgment, and disorientation. The diagnosis is supported by his Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score (13–20 points: moderate dementia). His clinical and laboratory workup for reversible causes of dementia (e.g., vitamin B12 deficiency, hypothyroidism, etc.) have been unremarkable.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 5 weeks. The patient had been living independently but came to live with his daughter temporarily after he told her that he was unable to perform some of his daily activities. He has left the front door wide open and tap water running on multiple occasions. The patient is concerned about his memory lapses. He wakes up 6–7 times during the night. He often feels too tired to leave his room and rarely makes conversation with his daughter. He says that he used to enjoy playing the piano but has not played for several months. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows orientation to person, place, and time as well as psychomotor retardation. He has a blunted affect. Attention, concentration, and short- and long-term memory are impaired. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and vitamin B12 are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Donepezil is indicated in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer dementia (AD). Patients with AD can present with impairment of daily life and, especially in early stages, show symptoms of depression. However, the onset of AD is usually insidious, with progression over ∼ 8–10 years. The memory of recent events is typically the cognitive domain affected first in patients with AD. For this reason, patients are typically not oriented to person, place, or time. Also, unlike this patient who is concerned about his memory loss, patients with AD are often not aware of their cognitive deficits.

B) CORRECT:

This patient meets 5 (anhedonia, sleep disturbance, diminished cognition, psychomotor changes, and low energy) out of the 9 diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD). In patients with late-life depression, cognitive deficits may resemble dementia (i.e., pseudodementia). Compared to patients with other types of dementia, patients with pseudodementia are more likely to be aware of and concerned about memory impairment. Cognitive deficits in MDD typically have a sudden onset and manifest after the mood symptoms (e.g., this patient lost interest in playing the piano several months ago). Treatment of the underlying depression, e.g., with SSRIs such as citalopram, may lead to remission of the depression and reversal of the cognitive deficits. In older patients in particular, different causes of dementia must be considered if memory impairment persists after appropriate treatment and an improvement in depressive symptoms.

See “Differential diagnosis of subtypes of dementia” table.

C) INCORRECT:

Antiplatelet drugs such as aspirin may be considered in patients with vascular dementia. This type of dementia may present with abrupt cognitive decline and stepwise deterioration. This patient has risk factors for vascular dementia such as hypertension and advanced age. However, his loss of interest, sleep disturbance, and psychomotor retardation cannot be explained by this diagnosis and warrant a different treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

A cerebral shunt is the treatment of choice for normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). While NPH typically manifests with impaired memory, other typical findings such as incontinence and ataxic gait are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

E) INCORRECT:

Memantine can be used in addition to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors in patients with moderate to severe Alzheimer dementia or vascular dementia. This patient's memory deficits could be explained by either of these dementia types, and depressive symptoms may occur in early dementia. However, his cognitive deficits are more likely to be caused by pseudodementia.
questions.hint: This patient's cognitive deficits are likely caused by pseudodementia.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for increased forgetfulness and unsteady gait over the past 3 months. He is a journalist and has had difficulty concentrating on his writing. He also complains of urinary urgency recently. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F) and blood pressure is 139/83 mm Hg. He is oriented only to person and place. He is able to recall 2 out of 3 words immediately and 1 out of 3 after five minutes. He has a slow, broad-based gait and takes short steps. Neurological examination is otherwise normal. Urinalysis is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease is the most common cause of dementia, with increasing prevalence after 60 years of age. Memory impairment is the cardinal and most common initial symptom, while behavioral symptoms, primitive reflexes, and urinary incontinence may manifest late in the disease course. The early development of gait disturbances in this patient is not typical of Alzheimer disease.

B) CORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) manifests with gait instability, cognitive disturbance, and urinary incontinence – the classic “wet, wacky, and wobbly” triad. Gait changes are typically symmetrical, while cognitive impairment primarily takes the form of decreased attention span and concentration. NPH is an important diagnosis to consider in a patient with dementia, as it may be reversible if the hydrocephalus is addressed (e.g., with a lumbar puncture to remove CSF). In most patients > 60 years of age, the accumulation of CSF is idiopathic, but it may also occur due to secondary causes (e.g., inflammation, hemorrhage) that lead to obstruction of the subarachnoid villi that normally resorb CSF in the ventricular system.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

C) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for vascular dementia include hypertension and dyslipidemia. Its clinical presentation is highly variable, as different regions of the brain may be involved in the vascular insults that lead to cognitive deterioration. Symptoms can include gait disturbances, personality and mood changes, and cognitive deficits, as well as cortical symptoms such as aphasia or amnesia. However, the development of deficits in vascular dementia usually occurs in a stepwise manner, while this patient's deficits developed in a short time period.

D) INCORRECT:

The hallmarks of frontotemporal dementia (FTD) are early, progressive aphasia or behavior and personality changes (e.g., disinhibition, apathy, hyperorality, and compulsive behaviors), which occur alongside degeneration of the frontal and/or temporal lobes. While this patient's performance on the five-minute recall test should raise suspicion for dementia, the lack of language dysfunction or personality changes and the presence of gait abnormalities make FTD an unlikely diagnosis in this case.
Image Description:

MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view)

There is atrophy of the left frontal (FL) and temporal lobe (TL) with prominence of the cerebrospinal fluid spaces (green overlay).

As the name suggests, frontotemporal dementia predominantly affects the frontal and temporal lobes. The specific pattern of brain atrophy varies by subtype. Although cerebral atrophy is often bilateral in frontotemporal dementia, it can be asymmetrical, as demonstrated in this example.

Because the majority of people develop some degree of brain atrophy as a part of normal aging, correlation with the clinical history is essential for this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Lewy body dementia is characterized by early impairment in attention and executive function, with memory impairment developing later in the disease course. Diagnosis requires two of the following: cognitive fluctuations, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism. While this patient demonstrates cognitive impairment, he does not have any hallucinations or features of parkinsonism, e.g., tremor or rigidity.
Image Description:

Microscopy of the substantia nigra of a patient with Parkinson disease (upper row: 60x magnification, lower row: 20x magnification; staining with antibodies against alpha-synuclein, counterstaining with Mayer hematoxylin)

Both Lewy bodies (spherical intracytoplasmic aggregates of alpha-synuclein; green overlay) and the strand-like Lewy neurites (neurites containing alpha-synuclein aggregates; white arrows) are visible.

F) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency develops after years of inadequate intake, malabsorption, or increased demand. The condition can manifest with symptoms such as memory impairment, personality changes, and paresthesias, which could lead to gait abnormalities. However, vitamin B12 deficiency typically results in loss of distal vibratory sense in the extremities (lower > upper), which is not present in this patient. Furthermore, urinary urgency would not be explained by B12 deficiency.
questions.hint: This patient's confusion, ataxic gait, and urinary symptoms suggest a cause of reversible dementia in older adults.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter for evaluation of impaired memory and word-finding difficulties for 2 years. She was recently asked to step down from her position as volunteer accountant for a local charity organization because she was no longer able to coordinate her tasks. She reports that she has become unable to taste or smell her food. Two years later, the patient dies. At autopsy, examination of the brain shows generalized cortical atrophy. A photomicrograph of a section of the brain is shown. The inclusions indicated by the arrows are predominantly composed of which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alpha-synuclein aggregates, among ubiquitin and neurofilaments, can be found in Lewy bodies, which constitute the underlying pathology of Lewy body dementia and Parkinson disease. Although Lewy body dementia can present with cognitive impairment, distinctive clinical features such as visual hallucinations or sleep behavior dysfunction were not present in this patient. Moreover, she did not have any symptoms of parkinsonism (e.g., tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia).
Image Description:

Microscopy of the substantia nigra of a patient with Parkinson disease (upper row: 60x magnification, lower row: 20x magnification; staining with antibodies against alpha-synuclein, counterstaining with Mayer hematoxylin)

Both Lewy bodies (spherical intracytoplasmic aggregates of alpha-synuclein; green overlay) and the strand-like Lewy neurites (neurites containing alpha-synuclein aggregates; white arrows) are visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Viral ribonuclear proteins (Negri bodies) can be found in the setting of rabies, as the virus reaches the brain through retrograde transport. They are seen as round cytoplasmic inclusions in Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and in hippocampal neurons. Even though rabies does cause CNS symptoms (confusion, seizures), dementia is not a feature. Moreover, rabies is typically lethal within days to weeks after onset of neurologic symptoms rather than gradually progressive as the dementia seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of autopsy specimen of brain tissue (H&E stain)

Negri bodies (examples indicated by green arrows) are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies present within the cell bodies and axons of neurons infected by the rabies virus. Although the presence of Negri bodies is pathognomonic of rabies, their absence does not rule out infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Amyloid-β, a derivative of amyloid precursor protein, accumulates in patients with Alzheimer disease and plays a major role of its underlying pathogenesis. This patient did have Alzheimer disease, but amyloid-β aggregates are found extracellularly in the form of senile plaques, not intracellularly as the inclusions seen in this image.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cerebral cortical tissue (H&E stain and anti-amyloid beta precursor protein immunostaining)

Multiple large red-brown extracellular structures are visible within the cortical matter. These are beta-amyloid plaques that have taken up the immunostain.

Accumulation of amyloid plaques in the interneuronal spaces of the brain is a characteristic feature of Alzheimer disease.

D) CORRECT:

Hyperphosphorylated tau constitutes the greater part of neurofibrillary tangles, which are seen in the photomicrograph. Tau proteins are microtubule-associated proteins that play a central role in the preservation of cell structure. Activation of glycogen synthase kinase-3 and other protein kinases induces increased phosphorylation of tau which leads to cluster formation and development of tangles. These tangles impair neuronal function and eventually cause neuronal death, which manifests as gradual onset of dementia, as was seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Abnormal prion proteins lead to deposition and formation of plaques, which promote cellular degeneration and ultimately neuronal death, as, e.g., in Creutzfeldt Jakob disease. Affected individuals classically present with rapidly progressive dementia in combination with myoclonus, not with the gradually developing symptoms over several years that were seen in this patient. In addition, brain autopsy would reveal not just atrophy but rather a characteristic pattern of spongiform encephalopathy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cortical brain tissue (H&E stain)

The tissue shows spongiform degeneration, which is the result of neuronal loss and the formation of numerous vacuoles of varying size (green overlay).

This is the characteristic histopathological appearance of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (detection of prions is only possible via immunohistochemistry).
questions.hint: This patient's memory deficits, amnesic aphasia, hyposmia (and associated hypogeusia), and generalized cortical atrophy are suggestive of Alzheimer disease, the most common type of dementia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for forgetfulness, confusion, and mood changes for the past 4 months. His symptoms started with misplacing items such as his wallet and keys around the house. Two months ago, he became unable to manage their finances as it became too difficult for him. Last week, he became lost while returning home from the grocery store. His wife reports that he shows “no emotion” and that he is seemingly not concerned by his recent symptoms. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, metformin, and rosuvastatin. His pulse is 56/min and blood pressure is 158/76 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows loss of sensation on his right leg and an unsteady gait. When asked to stand with his eyes closed and palms facing upward, his right arm rotates inward. An MRI of the brain shows multiple deep white matter lesions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation with a relatively abrupt cognitive decline and a stepwise deterioration in function (from misplacing items to being unable to manage finances to becoming lost in a familiar place) is suggestive of vascular dementia (i.e., multi-infarct dementia). The primary pathogenesis of this disease is atherosclerosis, for which diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and uncontrolled hypertension are risk factors. The diagnosis is further supported by the presence of neurologic deficits on examination, such as right-sided pronator drift, numbness in the right leg, and unsteady gait. The multiple deep white matter lesions on cranial MRI represent previous lacunar infarcts.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Abnormal low attenuation zones are seen in the periventricular white matter adjacent to the frontal and temporal horns of the lateral ventricles (green overlay). The cerebral sulci (examples indicated by red overlay) and ventricles are also prominent.

These findings may be seen in vascular dementia.

B) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia is associated with personality changes (e.g., apathy) and eventual decline in cognitive function. Physical examination may show pyramidal signs such as a pronator drift. However, cranial MRI is more likely to show atrophy of the frontal and/or temporal lobes than white matter lesions. Other features of frontotemporal dementia include disinhibition, loss of empathy, binge eating, and exaggerated emotional display.
Image Description:

MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view)

There is atrophy of the left frontal (FL) and temporal lobe (TL) with prominence of the cerebrospinal fluid spaces (green overlay).

As the name suggests, frontotemporal dementia predominantly affects the frontal and temporal lobes. The specific pattern of brain atrophy varies by subtype. Although cerebral atrophy is often bilateral in frontotemporal dementia, it can be asymmetrical, as demonstrated in this example.

Because the majority of people develop some degree of brain atrophy as a part of normal aging, correlation with the clinical history is essential for this condition.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's cognitive decline and apathy are possible features of Alzheimer disease, which is the most common cause of dementia in older adults. However, Alzheimer disease typically has a more insidious onset and slow progression with early memory loss rather than a rapid stepwise deterioration in executive function. Moreover, Alzheimer disease is unlikely to manifest with neurologic deficits on physical examination (e.g., pronator drift, numbness, abnormal gait) and MRI would show cerebral atrophy rather than white matter lesions.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with increasing memory disturbance

There is bilateral cerebral atrophy, with prominent sulci (green overlay).

Multiple small hyperintense foci in the white matter (examples outlined) are enlarged perivascular spaces (Virchow-Robin spaces).

D) INCORRECT:

Major depressive disorder is the most common cause of pseudodementia, for which this patient's age is a risk factor. Apathy is a feature of major depressive disorder; however, this patient does not meet the clinical criteria for depression. Moreover, pseudodementia is unlikely to present with neurologic deficits on physical examination (e.g., pronator drift, numbness, abnormal gait) and is not associated with white matter lesions on cranial MRI.

E) INCORRECT:

Lewy body dementia causes a variable sequence of symptoms that may include forgetfulness, confusion, and unsteady gait. However, physical examination would more likely show extrapyramidal motor symptoms (e.g., bradykinesia) than focal neurologic deficits (e.g., numbness, pronator drift). Other common features of Lewy body dementia not present in this patient include visual hallucinations and rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder. A cranial MRI would show regional cerebral atrophy rather than white matter lesions.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient's mood changes, forgetfulness, and bradycardia are possible features of hypothyroidism. However, this condition is not associated with focal neurologic deficits (e.g., numbness, pronator drift, abnormal gait). Other common features of hypothyroidism include fatigue, cold intolerance, skin and hair changes, weight gain, and constipation. This patient's bradycardia can be explained by metoprolol use and his mood changes and forgetfulness are more likely due to the abnormalities seen in his MRI.

G) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause a variety of neuropsychiatric symptoms, including apathy, forgetfulness, numbness, and unsteady gait. However, neuropathy would more likely be symmetrical and abnormal cranial MRI findings would be unlikely. Moreover, vitamin B12 deficiency typically manifests with signs of anemia (e.g., fatigue, pallor), scleral icterus, or glossitis.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical history (stepwise decline in executive function), physical examination (presence of focal neurologic deficits), and MRI findings (multiple deep white matter lesions) are suggestive of the second most common type of dementia in older individuals.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman is concerned that she has become more forgetful. She reports having difficulty remembering appointments and recalling the details of recent conversations. When driving, she increasingly relies on her in-car navigation system, even when traveling to places that she has visited several times before. She continues to work part-time as a history professor and has noticed some minor difficulties with word finding when lecturing to students. The symptoms have gradually progressed during the past 6 to 12 months.
She states that she has been worrying about her increasing forgetfulness and, as a result, has felt “down” lately. Her husband notes that she has not had trouble getting things done around the house and remains active in her religious community. A brief history reveals no change in sleep, energy, or appetite.
On bedside cognitive testing, she can recall only one out of three words and incorrectly copies two intersecting pentagons.
Her vital signs and neurologic examination are unremarkable.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease and vascular dementia both involve cognitive changes that are severe enough to cause significant impairment in social, occupational, or executive functioning. They can be difficult to tell apart clinically, but in general, the decline is gradual in Alzheimer disease and stepwise in vascular dementia.

B) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease and vascular dementia both involve cognitive changes that are severe enough to cause significant impairment in social, occupational, or executive functioning. They can be difficult to tell apart clinically, but in general, the decline is gradual in Alzheimer disease and stepwise in vascular dementia.

C) INCORRECT:

Normal aging is associated with a variety of cognitive changes, but when the changes exceed those seen with normal aging — such as the impaired recall of directions, conversations, and appointments described in this case — the possibility of MCI should be recognized and the patient should be evaluated further rather than having her complaints interpreted as representing normal aging.

D) INCORRECT:

Pseudodementia refers to the cognitive impairment, often linked with decreased effort or motivation, that may affect patients with depression or other primary psychiatric disorders. However, this patient does not meet the criteria for major depressive disorder (or any other psychiatric disorder).

E) CORRECT:

Mild symptoms of cognitive decline may be subtle and include misplacing objects or having difficulty with recall. Forgetting conversations and appointments are more worrisome aspects of a patient’s history. Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) can be diagnosed once subjective concern is coupled with objective findings on cognitive testing, such as reduced recall and difficulty drawing intersecting pentagons, as reported in this patient.

A diagnosis of MCI indicates that the patient does not experience functional impairment from cognitive problems and can often compensate for the cognitive impairment through use of calendars or, in this case, navigational systems. MCI can occur across multiple domains (such as executive function, visual-spatial, and expressive language), which is the most likely case for this patient.

Once MCI is diagnosed, the patient should be evaluated for reversible causes of cognitive impairment (such as vitamin B12 deficiency and hypothyroidism). Neuroimaging is also usually performed with either CT or MRI to ensure that reversible or secondary causes are not present.

Key learning point: When a patient experiences impairment in both memory and other cognitive domains (e.g., executive function, visual-spatial, expressive language) but does not have any significant functional impairment, the most likely diagnosis is amnestic mild cognitive impairment, multiple domains.

questions.text:
The son of a 71-year-old woman with a history of several strokes and vascular dementia reports that his mother has become more agitated and combative. Specifically, she is verbally abusing her daughter and her daytime caregiver. She often gets dressed late at night and wants to leave the house to run errands. The patient does not report pain or recent illness and denies depressive thoughts. Her only medications — aspirin 81 mg daily and lisinopril 20 mg daily — have not changed.
She is afebrile, and her blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. On examination, her Folstein Mini-Mental Status Examination score is 14 out of 30, consistent with moderate dementia. The rest of her examination is normal, except for a mild left hemiparesis.
A urine dipstick result is normal. Her last fasting LDL-cholesterol level, checked 3 months ago, was 70 mg/dL (reference range, <130).
Which one of the following approaches is the most appropriate first step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lamotrigine, an anticonvulsant drug used primarily to treat seizures and bipolar disorder, has not been shown to be effective in treating agitation in patients with dementia.

B) CORRECT:

Neurobehavioral abnormalities increase in prevalence with advancing dementia and often lead to progressive functional impairment, institutionalization, and caregiver distress. Common causes of such abnormalities in cognitively impaired patients include acute medical illness, adverse effects of medications, failure to address basic needs, environmental factors, and interpersonal issues. After excluding medication-related effects or delirium secondary to infection or pain, the clinician should evaluate whether the patient’s basic needs are being met — including hydration, nutrition, normal sleep-wake cycles, personal hygiene, adequate clothing, mobilization, normal bowel and bladder function, and pain relief — and then determine if there are environmental triggers or strains.

Nonpharmacologic interventions for patients with neurobehavioral abnormalities include avoiding physical restraints; promoting reassuring interpersonal interactions, a consistent daily routine, and normal sleep-wake cycles; minimizing excessive noise or overstimulation; providing reorientation, companionship, and complementary therapy (music, art, pet, structured exercise, and massage); and educating caregivers. The effectiveness of nonpharmacologic interventions still needs to be studied rigorously, but these interventions are safer than drug treatment.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first step in managing behavioral issues in a patient with dementia is a nonpharmacologic (behavioral) intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Although atypical antipsychotics, such as olanzapine, are often prescribed to patients with dementia, adverse events in older adults (falls, strokes, weight gain, and death) have led the Food and Drug Administration to mandate a black-box warning for this class of drugs. Moreover, the Clinical Antipsychotic Trials of Intervention Effectiveness-Alzheimer Disease (CATIE-AD) compared three different atypical antipsychotics (quetiapine, olanzapine, and risperidone) with placebo and failed to document a clinically significant improvement with any of them.

D) INCORRECT:

A few trials have shown benefits of selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors, such as citalopram, but in older adults, these medications may cause serious adverse effects, including an increase in neurobehavorial abnormalities, hyponatremia, falls, and fractures.

E) INCORRECT:

Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors, such as donepezil, do not appear to improve behavioral outcomes in patients with vascular dementia.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman with Alzheimer disease, seasonal allergies, atrial fibrillation, and type 2 diabetes has experienced a subacute decline in her cognitive function. According to her family members, she has become more confused, often forgets to take her medications, and has difficulty recognizing familiar people.
The patient and her family noticed subtle improvement in her cognitive abilities when she started taking donepezil 5 mg daily one year ago. Her other medications are atenolol, apixaban, lisinopril, and metformin. She has not been sick recently, but an increase in seasonal allergies led to recent initiation of diphenhydramine.
Her Folstein Mini-Mental Status Examination score has declined from 23/30 to 19/30, the latter representing a moderate range of dementia, with very poor delayed recall and orientation. Otherwise, her general and neurologic examinations are normal. Her blood pressure is 106/74 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 62 beats per minute. Her dipstick urinalysis is normal.
Which one of the following medication changes is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Changing the dose of donepezil is unlikely to improve the patient’s symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing atenolol is unlikely to improve cognitive performance in a patient who has a normal heart rate and blood pressure.

C) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing donepezil is unlikely to improve the patient’s symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with Alzheimer disease, a gradual decline in cognition is to be expected despite use of an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. On average, there is an annual decline of 3 to 4 points on the Mini-Mental Status Examination. However, a subacute decline usually indicates a superimposed disorder, most often an infection (e.g., of the urinary tract) or a medication effect.

Anticholinergic agents, such as diphenhydramine, are relatively contraindicated in older patients with Alzheimer disease, who already have a cholinergic deficit. Several medication classes — including sedative antihistamines, tricyclic antidepressants, bladder antispasmodics, and numerous over-the-counter medications — have anticholinergic effects. Patients with Alzheimer disease vary in their tolerance of these medications; factors affecting tolerance include the dose, the patient’s cognitive reserve, hepatic and renal function, and the number of other medications being used.

Key learning point: A subacute decline in neurocognitive performance in a patient with Alzheimer disease is most frequently attributable to an infection or a new medication.

E) INCORRECT:

Adding an antipsychotic medication, such as risperidone, is not recommended for patients with Alzheimer disease, because the drug may have serious adverse effects, including increased mortality risk.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman with well-controlled type 2 diabetes reports that she fell twice during the past 3 months but did not sustain any significant injury. She reports instability while standing, difficulty getting out of a car, trouble initiating gait, and a tendency to tip over while making sharp turns.
Her husband has noticed some impairment in her short-term memory, but she has no functional impairments and is independent in her activities of daily living. She also reports urinary urgency and the need to wake up two or three times a night to pass urine, although she is not incontinent. She has no pain in her back, hips, or knees.
Her vital signs are normal, and she does not have orthostasis. Her vision, hearing, peripheral circulation, and joint examinations are normal. Her Folstein Mini-Mental Status Examination score is 26 out of 30. Her neurologic examination reveals normal extraocular movements, as well as normal axial and appendicular tone with intact power and coordination. She has diminished pinprick and temperature sensation in her feet, but her large-fiber modalities (vibration and position sense) and deep-tendon reflexes are normal. Her gait is wide-based, she takes short steps, and she has a tendency to drag both feet.
Her most recent glycated hemoglobin measurement was 6.7% (reference range, 4.3–5.6). An MRI of the brain is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Parkinson-plus syndromes, such as progressive supranuclear palsy, can occasionally manifest predominantly with gait dysfunction accompanied by mild cognitive impairment and urinary symptoms. However, the absence of extrapyramidal findings on neurologic examination, a lack of abnormalities in extraocular eye movements, the absence of orthostasis, and normal coordination examination make those diagnoses less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Although autonomic neuropathy may be associated with urinary symptoms, it is most typically associated with gastroparesis and postural hypotension, not with cognitive impairment.

C) INCORRECT:

Parkinson-plus syndromes, such as multiple-system atrophy, can occasionally manifest predominantly with gait dysfunction accompanied by mild cognitive impairment and urinary symptoms. However, the absence of extrapyramidal findings on neurologic examination, a lack of abnormalities in extraocular eye movements, the absence of orthostasis, and normal coordination examination make those diagnoses less likely.

D) CORRECT:

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is typically characterized by a triad of gait impairment, cognitive impairment, and urinary dysfunction. Not all patients with NPH have the textbook “gait apraxia,” and the triad is neither necessary nor sufficient to consider the diagnosis. NPH is potentially reversible if detected early and if the right candidates are selected for shunt surgery. Positive response to supplementary tests — such as a large-volume lumbar puncture, extended cerebrospinal fluid diversion by a lumbar spinal catheter, or cerebrospinal fluid outflow resistance tests — increases the likelihood of a response to shunt surgery.

Many other disorders in older adults that manifest with similar symptoms and signs can often be excluded with careful neurologic examination and imaging. The most common disorder that mimics NPH is vascular dementia. However, this patient has no clinical history of a stroke, and the MRI scan does not reveal large-vessel infarcts or subcortical ischemic changes that would suggest a vascular etiology. The scan reveals dilation of the ventricular system, including the third and fourth ventricles. NPH is characterized by enlarged ventricles on imaging, with normal opening pressure on lumbar puncture.

Key learning point: The triad of gait impairment, cognitive impairment, and urinary dysfunction is most consistent with a diagnosis of normal-pressure hydrocephalus.

E) INCORRECT:

The most common disorder that mimics normal-pressure hydrocephalus is vascular dementia. However, this patient has no clinical history of a stroke, and the MRI scan does not reveal large-vessel infarcts or subcortical ischemic changes that would suggest a vascular etiology.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman reports a 9-month history of difficulty with her gait and balance as well as progressive cognitive decline. She has had two falls, has difficulty walking on uneven surfaces, has a tendency to shuffle, and has trouble getting in and out of chairs. More recently, in the past 3 months, she has also noticed some difficulty with her short-term memory and urinary urgency, along with occasional incontinence that she had not experienced before.
Her vital signs and physical examination are normal. Her gait is wide-based, and her feet point outward; she takes short steps and has a tendency to drag both feet. Her Folstein Mini-Mental Status Examination score is 22 out of 30. Her eye movements are normal. She has no resting or action tremor, and her tone, motor strength, reflexes, position sense, and vibration sense are normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients who have dementia with Lewy bodies usually present with fluctuations in sensorium, visual hallucinations, and cognitive impairment along with features of parkinsonism.

B) CORRECT:

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) classically manifests with abnormal gait, urinary incontinence, and cognitive impairment. The gait is bradykinetic, broad-based, magnetic, and shuffling. Urinary symptoms include increased frequency, urgency, or frank incontinence. Cognitive impairment can manifest with memory problems, psychomotor slowing, and executive dysfunction. Although this triad is suggestive of NPH, recent studies have shown it is neither necessary nor sufficient for the diagnosis of NPH. Supplemental testing with a large-volume lumbar puncture, an extended cerebrospinal-fluid drainage trial, or measurement of resistance to cerebrospinal fluid outflow is essential to select the correct patients for shunt surgery.

Key learning point: The diagnosis suggested by the findings of abnormal gait, urinary incontinence, and cognitive impairment with predominant and early onset of gait dysfunction is normal-pressure hydrocephalus.

C) INCORRECT:

Multiple-system atrophy can cause gait abnormalities and urinary incontinence similar to NPH, but patients typically have autonomic findings (orthostatic hypotension) and extrapyramidal or cerebellar dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Although patients with Parkinson disease can present with predominant gait symptoms, they frequently have bradykinesia, an asymmetric resting tremor, and rigidity.

E) INCORRECT:

Common symptoms of progressive supranuclear palsy include axial rigidity and eye-movement abnormalities (especially limitations of vertical gaze).

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man with atrial fibrillation and prior left-middle cerebral-artery stroke presents with his wife for an urgent care visit. He has had a fever and productive cough for the past 3 days and noticed this morning that he was dragging his right foot when he walked. He had similar but more severe symptoms with his stroke 5 years ago but recovered almost entirely back to baseline and has had no weakness until this morning. He reports that he has been taking his warfarin faithfully since he was started on it 22 years ago but has not had an international normalized ratio measured recently.
On examination, he has a fever of 38.9°C, a heart rate of 92 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 148/68 mm Hg. Cardiac examination reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm with no murmur, and he has subtle end-expiratory wheezes at both lung bases. His mental status and cranial nerve examinations are normal. He is able to name both low- and high-frequency words and can also repeat and follow simple and complex commands.
He has no back pain and no sensory deficits, except for a right pronator drift and dragging of his right foot while walking. His wife notes that he is steadier during the examination than he was early this morning. All extremities exhibit 5/5 strength on confrontation testing, and reflexes are normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

choices.text: Postictal weakness after seizure, related to febrile illness

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In this case, the patient has an unknown international normalized ratio and significant risk factors for stroke, including suboptimally controlled blood pressure at the time of the examination. This raises the possibility of a new embolic or lacunar stroke. However, the patient reports adherence to his medications, and his current deficits are similar to but less severe than his initial presentation, they occurred in the setting of illness, and they now seem to be improving — all of which make recrudescence more likely than a new stroke. It would be very unlikely for a new stroke to cause exactly the same symptoms as the first, especially a lacunar stroke, which is a different mechanism from this patient’s first stroke.

B) CORRECT:

Patients who have had neurologic deficits as a result of stroke or multiple sclerosis sometimes experience reemergence or recrudescence of those deficits in the setting of an intercurrent illness. The most common triggers include infection, hypotension, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, insomnia, stress, and benzodiazepine use. Recrudescence occurs most commonly with middle cerebral-artery infarcts and can lead to language, sensory, and motor deficits. Gaze preference, hemianopsia, and neglect are not typically observed.

Recrudescence is often a diagnosis of exclusion and must be distinguished from a new neurologic event. The symptoms experienced during recrudescence are typically similar to those of the initial presentation but less severe. If symptoms occur that were not present at the time of the initial injury, they should be evaluated as a possible new event.

Key learning point: When patients with prior stroke experience recrudescence, the symptoms are usually similar to their initial presentation but not as severe.

C) INCORRECT:

The asymmetry of his symptoms and lack of proximal weakness make a new progressive myopathy unlikely, particularly at the age of 82.

D) INCORRECT:

Although seizure can occur in the setting of infection and can lead to a Todd paralysis (transient unilateral postictal weakness, often contralateral to the site of seizure onset), this patient has no reports of seizure activity or any other findings, such as incontinence, that might suggest seizure.

E) INCORRECT:

In this case, the patient has an unknown international normalized ratio and significant risk factors for stroke, including suboptimally controlled blood pressure at the time of the examination. This raises the possibility of a new embolic or lacunar stroke. However, the patient reports adherence to his medications, and his current deficits are similar to but less severe than his initial presentation, they occurred in the setting of illness, and they now seem to be improving — all of which make recrudescence more likely than a new stroke. It would be very unlikely for a new stroke to cause exactly the same symptoms as the first, especially a lacunar stroke, which is a different mechanism from this patient’s first stroke.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis of the knees presents with concerns about his memory. He is accompanied by his partner of 40 years, who reports that he needs constant reminders about current events and has lost interest in socializing with old friends because he has difficulty following conversations. He is independent in all activities of daily living, including showering, dressing, toileting, and eating; however, he depends on his partner for instrumental activities of daily living, including driving, medication management, food preparation, and money management. He has no history of traumatic brain injury and reports no feelings of depression or problems with sleep or hearing.
His current medications are lisinopril, simvastatin, and acetaminophen. He does not take any over-the-counter medications and does not drink alcohol.
His vital signs and neurologic examination are both normal. His score on the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ)-2 is 1 out of 6, making depression unlikely.
His laboratory results — including differential blood count; kidney, liver, and thyroid function; electrolyte, glucose, vitamin D, and vitamin B12 levels; and rapid plasma reagin and HIV testing — are all normal, as is an MRI of the head.
Montreal Cognitive Assessment shows deficits in executive function and delayed recall; his final score is 18 out of 30 (≥26 is considered normal).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

When evaluating patients with memory impairment, clinicians should be sure to rule out other factors that could impair memory and function, including adverse effects of medications or toxins (such as benzodiazepines, opioids, antihistamines, muscle relaxants, and alcohol). This patient is not taking any high-risk medications, he does not drink alcohol, and his other diagnostic studies do not suggest other causes of cognitive impairment.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s memory impairment is affecting his daily functioning to the point that he cannot perform instrumental activities of daily living (IADLs), which require complex planning and thinking. He also shows signs of impaired social functioning. These findings raise concern for dementia (major neurocognitive disorder), which is defined as progressive cognitive impairment that has become severe enough to compromise the patient’s social functioning, occupational functioning, or both.

Although older age is a major risk factor for dementia, dementia is not a normal part of aging. The most common type of dementia is Alzheimer disease, followed by vascular dementia and then mixed dementia, which involves pathophysiological features of more than one type (such as Alzheimer disease and vascular dementia). Other types of dementia include Parkinson dementia, frontotemporal dementia, Lewy body dementia, and dementia related to alcohol use.

The Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) is one of many available screening tests to aid in diagnosing dementia in patients who present with memory concerns and functional decline. It assesses several cognitive domains including executive function, verbal fluency, attention, language, abstraction, delayed recall, and orientation. A score of ≤26 is considered abnormal and, in conjunction with other parts of a patient’s history, can help to determine the diagnosis.

This patient scored 18 on the MoCA, with demonstrated deficits in executive function and delayed recall. These findings, together with his history of functional impairment and the absence of an alternative explanation, are suggestive of dementia. Patients who have difficulty with executive function often demonstrate difficulty with IADLs that require planning and organization, such as medication and financial management.

When evaluating patients with memory impairment, clinicians should be sure to rule out other factors that could impair memory and function, including depression, thyroid dysfunction, electrolyte abnormalities (such as hyper- or hypocalcemia), vitamin deficiencies (mainly vitamin B12), underlying infections (such as syphilis), adverse effects of medications or toxins (such as benzodiazepines, opioids, antihistamines, muscle relaxants, and alcohol), and central nervous system pathology. In this case, the patient has a low likelihood of depression (given his normal score on the Patient Health Questionnaire [PHQ]-2), although further workup with the PHQ-9 or the Geriatric Depression Scale could be considered. He is not taking any high-risk medications, he does not drink alcohol, and his other diagnostic studies do not suggest other causes of cognitive impairment.

Neuropsychological testing may be useful for further confirming and characterizing the nature of the disorder.

Key learning point: Dementia (also known as major neurocognitive disorder) is characterized by progressive cognitive impairment that has become severe enough to compromise the patient’s social functioning, occupational functioning, or both.

C) INCORRECT:

When evaluating patients with memory impairment, clinicians should be sure to rule out other factors that could impair memory and function, including depression. In this case, the patient has a low likelihood of depression (given his normal score on the Patient Health Questionnaire [PHQ]-2), although further workup with the PHQ-9 or the Geriatric Depression Scale could be considered.

D) INCORRECT:

Mild cognitive impairment (also known as minor neurocognitive disorder) is characterized by memory impairment beyond that expected for age and education level but not severe enough to affect the patient’s social or occupational functioning. Patients with this condition typically present with abnormal MoCA scores but intact ADLs and IADLs. Given that this patient has an abnormal MoCA score and depends on his partner for some IADLs, with no other explanation found, he likely has dementia.

E) INCORRECT:

Delirium is characterized by an acute change in cognition and attention. This patient is exhibiting chronic (not acute) changes in his cognition, and no other underlying causes have been noted.

questions.text:
A 91-year-old man with a history of Alzheimer dementia, type 2 diabetes, and osteoarthritis presents with his son for concern about poor oral intake. He has previously required assistance with bathing and grooming but not feeding and has been on a pureed diet. However, his son reports that during the past week, he has become agitated during meals and refused to eat. When his son has tried to feed him, he has spit out the food or refused to open his mouth. His weight is stable.
On physical examination, he is nonverbal and appears to be uncomfortable. His vital signs are unremarkable. Examination of the heart and lungs is normal. The abdomen is soft, nontender, and nondistended.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Start a trial of an antipsychotic medication

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pain is often difficult to identify in people living with dementia because they may have difficulty communicating their pain. Untreated pain is a common precipitator of behavioral changes and delirium in patients with dementia. Thus, when a patient with dementia presents with new behavioral changes, the clinician should evaluate for pain as a possible cause.

In this case, the patient’s reluctance to eat suggests the possibility of orofacial pain, most likely related to dental pain; thus, the most appropriate next step is a dental examination. Many studies suggest that patients with Alzheimer dementia are more likely to have tooth decay, dental infections, and tooth loss than the general population. In addition, older adults with dentures may experience discomfort if the structure of their mouth and jaw changes with age and their dentures no longer fit properly.

Key learning point: New behavioral changes in a patient with dementia should prompt evaluation for previously unrecognized pain.

B) INCORRECT:

Providing reassurance alone would be inadequate in this scenario. The patient appears to be uncomfortable on examination after presenting with an acute change in function (i.e., refusal to eat). Patients with dementia who have an abrupt change in function warrant additional investigation if it is within their goals of care to identify a reversible cause of their behavior. Furthermore, it is always important to determine whether a patient is in pain and, if appropriate, to offer treatment. The PAINAD scale (Pain Assessment in Advanced Dementia) may be useful for diagnosing pain in a patient with dementia who is nonverbal; it assesses breathing, negative vocalization, facial expression, body language, and consolability.

C) INCORRECT:

Removing dietary restrictions can increase a patient’s desire to eat and their enjoyment of food, thus reducing the risk for weight loss and undernutrition. Patients with dental pain may refuse to eat certain foods, particularly those that are hard, cold, sweet, or hot. Although moving this patient away from a pureed diet may be appropriate in the future, the first step is to understand the reason for his reluctance to eat.

D) INCORRECT:

Although analgesia may be warranted if this patient is in pain, the source of the pain should be identified first so that it can be addressed if appropriate. Orofacial pain can be caused by dental infection, tooth decay, temporomandibular joint disorders, and other oral lesions. An assessment for these potential causes of pain is indicated before any pain medication is started.

E) INCORRECT:

Low-dose antipsychotic agents may be indicated for patients with severe, agitated behavior who are threatening harm to themselves or others, but that is not the case with this patient. His behavior change may have been precipitated by pain, and the focus should be on evaluating for that before considering medications targeted at the behavior.

questions.text:
A 92-year-old man who resides in a long-term care facility is being evaluated in the emergency department after he was found on the floor near his bed following an unwitnessed fall with suspected fracture. His medical history includes hypertension, arthritis, hyperlipidemia, benign prostatic hyperplasia, depression, advanced Alzheimer dementia, and recurrent falls. At baseline, he is minimally verbal and nonambulatory, and he is dependent on others for all of his activities of daily living, including toileting and transferring.
On physical examination, the patient’s left lower extremity is shortened and externally rotated. His temperature is 38.1°C, with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and a heart rate of 104 beats per minute. His eyes are closed, his fists are clenched, and he grimaces and moans when you attempt to examine his legs, although he stops moaning when you hold his hand. As you arrange for imaging and further assessment, you use the Pain Assessment in Advanced Dementia (PAINAD) scale to assess his baseline pain score and monitor his response to pain medication.
In addition to consolability, facial expression, body language, and vocalization, which one of the following features should be included in an assessment of this patient’s pain according to the PAINAD scale?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Many patients with advanced dementia may lose the ability to communicate their needs, especially in acute-care settings where they may be isolated from family members and caretakers who know them and their baseline behaviors well. In addition, patients with dementia are more prone to delirium when they are in pain or hospitalized, making it even more difficult for them to communicate their pain.

The Pain Assessment in Advanced Dementia (PAINAD) scale was developed for bedside evaluation of pain severity in patients with advanced dementia who may be minimally verbal or nonverbal at baseline. It includes five components of nonverbal communication, each scored numerically from 0 to 2, with higher scores indicating increased severity of pain, as shown in the table below.

In this case, the patient would receive at least 1 point for hyperventilation, at least 1 point for consolability (he stopped moaning when his hand was held), at least 1 point for body language (clenched fists), 2 points for facial expression (grimacing), and at least 1 point for negative vocalization (moaning). His total score would be ≥6 points, corresponding to at least moderate pain.

Regular pain assessment and management of patients with advanced dementia who may not be able to communicate is an essential part of person-centered care.

Key learning point: One available tool for objectively assessing pain severity in patients with advanced dementia who cannot communicate effectively is the Pain Assessment in Advanced Dementia (PAINAD) scale. It evaluates five forms of nonverbal communication: negative vocalization, facial expression, body language, consolability, and breathing.

B) INCORRECT:

Although delirium can be caused by pain, it is not part of the PAINAD scale.

C) INCORRECT:

Bowel incontinence is not part of the PAINAD scale.

D) INCORRECT:

Although tachycardia can be caused by pain, it is not part of the PAINAD scale.

E) INCORRECT:

Although fever can be caused by pain, it is not part of the PAINAD scale.

questions.text:
A 94-year-old man with a history of Alzheimer disease, coronary artery disease, hypertension, and hearing loss presents for a virtual video appointment (telehealth visit) because of decreased appetite and weight loss. His niece is present at the appointment and reports that for the past few months, he has been coughing at meals and having trouble swallowing. During the past 6 months, he has been admitted to the hospital twice for aspiration pneumonia and has lost 5.5 kg. He has profound memory deficits and is mostly nonverbal and bedbound. He is unable to perform activities of daily living such as bathing, dressing, or transferring independently. His niece is his health care proxy and primary caregiver. She is tearful and wants to discuss treatment options to improve his appetite and swallowing problems and wonders whether the patient should get a feeding tube.
On examination, he appears frail with temporal wasting. He can smile but does not answer questions or follow commands. His vital signs and the rest of the examination are unremarkable. Laboratory tests are unremarkable.
What is the best next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Share that the patient’s dementia is advanced and recommend that he be enrolled in hospice
Explain that tube feeding is not associated with prolonged survival in patients with advanced dementia
Ask the niece what her treatment goals are for the care of her uncle
Suggest a time-limited trial of an appetite stimulant medication
Refer the patient to a speech and language pathologist for a swallowing evaluation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients at or beyond stage 7c on the FAST tool qualify for hospice in the setting of other comorbidities, including aspiration pneumonias. This patient is likely at stage 7d and therefore qualifies for hospice. However, a recommendation to initiate hospice should be preceded by a conversation about the patient’s goals of care.

B) INCORRECT:

Considering enteral feeding, for example via a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube, may seem like an attractive option to provide nutrition to patients who cannot keep up with nutritional demands due to dysphagia or food refusal. However, the use of percutaneous feeding tubes is associated with high rates of complications, including worsening agitation. Therefore, the American Geriatrics Society (AGS)’s Choosing Wisely recommendation is to avoid the use of percutaneous feeding tubes in patients with advanced dementia. A recommended alternative is careful hand-feeding, which can alleviate concerns about leaving the patient without nutrition. This can be formalized in the form of a “feeding for comfort” order that creates an individualized feeding care plan to state what steps are to be taken to ensure the patient's comfort.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has advanced dementia, as demonstrated by his functional dependence, loss of verbal and ambulatory abilities, and feeding difficulties. Advanced care planning is an important aspect of care for patients with advanced dementia, although goals-of-care conversations should ideally be undertaken before dementia has impaired the patient’s decision-making ability. Clinicians should assess how much the patient or surrogate decision maker understands about the disease trajectory and expected clinical outcomes and then educate them accordingly. Clinicians should also counsel surrogate decision makers to consider what treatments would be consistent with the patient’s values and wishes if the patient is unable to participate in decision-making. In this case, the most appropriate next step before recommending a treatment plan is to ask the niece open-ended questions to gain a better understanding of the patient and his family’s perspectives, expectations, and goals.

Despite all of the evidence and recommendations against placement of percutaneous feeding tubes in this scenario, it is not advisable to start the conversation with the patient and caregiver by explaining that percutaneous feeding tubes are not associated with prolonged survival. Doing so is likely to alienate the niece, she might interpret this statement as an attempt to withhold care, or she might perceive percutaneous feeding tubes to be acceptable if life can be prolonged. Importantly, any discussion about supplemental feeding should be preceded by defining both the patient’s and the proxy’s understanding and wishes.

This patient has advanced dementia and likely qualifies for hospice. The progression of dementia can be assessed by the Functional Assessment Staging Tool (FAST), a scale ranging from stage 1 to stage 7f, with the latter representing the most severe dementia.

Key learning point: Treatment decisions for patients with advanced dementia and feeding difficulties should be guided by discussions about goals of care.

D) INCORRECT:

Suggesting a time-limited trial of a prescription appetite stimulant for this patient without understanding the niece’s perspective would not be appropriate. In addition, the AGS Choosing Wisely guidelines recommend avoiding prescription appetite stimulants for the treatment of cachexia and anorexia in older adults. Care should focus instead on clarifying the patient’s goals and expectations. One can also consider discontinuing medications that may interfere with eating, evaluating for dental or oral problems, optimizing social supports, and encouraging the provision of appealing foods and feeding assistance.

E) INCORRECT:

Referring this patient for a swallowing evaluation before initiating a goals-of-care conversation would be inappropriate. Dysphagia commonly occurs in people with Alzheimer disease, particularly as the disease severity progresses. However, it is important to clarify the goals of the patient and his caregiver before making a referral for a swallowing evaluation. The clinician should begin by asking open-ended questions to learn about the niece’s perspective and then discuss which options should be explored that will allow her to make the decision that best aligns with her uncle’s goals and values.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a past medical history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease is brought to the office by his wife for forgetfulness and confusion for the past 4 months. His symptoms started with misplacing items around the house. Two months ago, he became unable to manage their finances as it became too difficult for him. Last week, he became lost while returning home from the grocery store. His wife reports that he is seemingly not concerned by his recent symptoms. Neurologic examination shows loss of sensation on his right leg and an unsteady gait. When asked to stand with his eyes closed and palms facing upward, his right arm rotates inward. An MRI of the brain shows multiple deep white matter lesions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation with a relatively abrupt cognitive decline and a stepwise deterioration in function (from misplacing items to being unable to manage finances to becoming lost in a familiar place) is suggestive of vascular dementia (i.e., multi-infarct dementia). The primary pathogenesis of this disease is atherosclerosis, for which diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and uncontrolled hypertension are risk factors. The diagnosis is further supported by the presence of neurologic deficits on examination, such as right-sided pronator drift, numbness in the right leg, and unsteady gait. The multiple deep white matter lesions on cranial MRI represent previous lacunar infarcts.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Abnormal low attenuation zones are seen in the periventricular white matter adjacent to the frontal and temporal horns of the lateral ventricles (green overlay). The cerebral sulci (examples indicated by red overlay) and ventricles are also prominent.

These findings may be seen in vascular dementia.

B) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia is associated with personality changes (e.g., apathy) and eventual decline in cognitive function. Physical examination may show pyramidal signs such as a pronator drift. However, cranial MRI is more likely to show atrophy of the frontal and/or temporal lobes than white matter lesions. Other features of frontotemporal dementia include disinhibition, loss of empathy, binge eating, and exaggerated emotional display.
Image Description:

MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view)

There is atrophy of the left frontal (FL) and temporal lobe (TL) with prominence of the cerebrospinal fluid spaces (green overlay).

As the name suggests, frontotemporal dementia predominantly affects the frontal and temporal lobes. The specific pattern of brain atrophy varies by subtype. Although cerebral atrophy is often bilateral in frontotemporal dementia, it can be asymmetrical, as demonstrated in this example.

Because the majority of people develop some degree of brain atrophy as a part of normal aging, correlation with the clinical history is essential for this condition.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's cognitive decline and apathy are possible features of Alzheimer disease, which is the most common cause of dementia in older adults. However, Alzheimer disease typically has a more insidious onset and slow progression with early memory loss rather than a rapid stepwise deterioration in executive function. Moreover, Alzheimer disease is unlikely to manifest with neurologic deficits on physical examination (e.g., pronator drift, numbness, abnormal gait) and MRI would show cerebral atrophy rather than white matter lesions.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with increasing memory disturbance

There is bilateral cerebral atrophy, with prominent sulci (green overlay).
