Multiple small hyperintense foci in the white matter (examples outlined) are enlarged perivascular spaces (Virchow-Robin spaces).

D) INCORRECT:

Lewy body dementia causes a variable sequence of symptoms that may include forgetfulness, confusion, and unsteady gait. However, physical examination would more likely show extrapyramidal motor symptoms (e.g., bradykinesia) than focal neurologic deficits (e.g., numbness, pronator drift). Other common features of Lewy body dementia not present in this patient include visual hallucinations and rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder. A cranial MRI would show regional cerebral atrophy rather than white matter lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause a variety of neuropsychiatric symptoms, including apathy, forgetfulness, numbness, and unsteady gait. However, neuropathy would more likely be symmetrical and abnormal cranial MRI findings would be unlikely. Moreover, vitamin B12 deficiency typically manifests with signs of anemia (e.g., fatigue, pallor), scleral icterus, or glossitis.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical history (stepwise decline in executive function), physical examination (presence of focal neurologic deficits), and MRI findings (multiple deep white matter lesions) are suggestive of the second most common type of dementia in older individuals.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman is brought to the office by her son because he is concerned about her forgetfulness for the past 2 years. She occasionally walks into a room and forgets why she went there and often forgets where she left her keys. She is sometimes unable to recall a familiar individual's name. She lives independently and goes shopping, cooks her own meals, and plays bridge with her friends every weekend. She has hypertension that is managed with hydrochlorothiazide. Examination shows a normal gait. She describes her mood as “good”; her thought process is organized and her judgment is intact. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mild memory impairment, occasional difficulties in word finding, and slower cognitive processing are normal effects of aging. An important distinguishing factor between normal aging and forms of dementia is the degree to which independence with everyday activities is impaired. In normal aging, independence in daily activities is preserved. Because this patient lives independently and her cognitive exams are within normal limits, dementia is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with Alzheimer disease present with progressive cognitive decline that can manifest with short term memory loss. Often, patients are unaware of their difficulties and relatives may express concern before the patient does. While this patient's son does express concern over her memory loss, her daily life is largely unaffected. Moreover, the cognitive dysfunction in Alzheimer disease is often accompanied by behavioral changes (such as aggression, depression, insomnia), which are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) presents with changes in personality and behavior (e.g., apathy), especially inappropriate social behavior in early stages (e.g., disinhibition), which this 82-year-old woman does not show. Additionally, the onset of FTD usually occurs in middle-aged individuals (40–60 years).

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with vascular dementia will present with a stepwise decline in cognitive and neurological function causing interference with independence in everyday activities. This patient has a risk factor for cerebrovascular disease (hypertension), but the minor memory loss in this patient is not consistent with the degree of cognitive impairment seen in vascular dementia. Moreover, cognitive impairment is often associated with other focal neurological deficits (e.g., hemiparesis, urinary incontinence, gait disturbance), which are absent in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

The degree of cognitive decline in normal pressure hydrocephalus is generally more severe than the minor memory loss seen in this patient. Normal pressure hydrocephalus presents with the classic triad of “wet, wobbly, and wacky” (urinary incontinence, gait disorder, and dementia), which this patient lacks.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).
questions.hint: These cognitive defects have not interfered with independence in everyday activities of this individual's life.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the office by his daughter because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 5 weeks. The patient had been living independently but came to live with his daughter temporarily because he is concerned about his memory lapses. He has left the front door wide open and tap water running on multiple occasions. He wakes up 6–7 times during the night. He often feels too tired to leave his room. He says that he used to enjoy playing the piano but has not played for several months. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. Mental status examination shows orientation to person, place, and time, a blunted affect, and psychomotor retardation. Attention, concentration, and short- and long-term memory are impaired. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Laboratory results are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Donepezil is indicated in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer dementia (AD). Patients with AD can present with impairment of daily life and, especially in early stages, show symptoms of depression. However, the onset of AD is usually insidious, with progression over ∼ 8–10 years. The memory of recent events is typically the cognitive domain affected first in patients with AD. For this reason, patients are typically not oriented to person, place, or time. Also, unlike this patient who is concerned about his memory loss, patients with AD are often not aware of their cognitive deficits.

B) CORRECT:

This patient meets 5 (anhedonia, sleep disturbance, diminished cognition, psychomotor changes, and low energy) out of the 9 diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD). In patients with late-life depression, cognitive deficits may resemble dementia (i.e., pseudodementia). Compared to patients with other types of dementia, patients with pseudodementia are more likely to be aware of and concerned about memory impairment. Cognitive deficits in MDD typically have a sudden onset and manifest after the mood symptoms (e.g., this patient lost interest in playing the piano several months ago). Treatment of the underlying depression, e.g., with SSRIs such as citalopram, may lead to remission of the depression and reversal of the cognitive deficits. In older patients in particular, different causes of dementia must be considered if memory impairment persists after appropriate treatment and an improvement in depressive symptoms.

See “Differential diagnosis of subtypes of dementia” table.

C) INCORRECT:

Antiplatelet drugs such as aspirin may be considered in patients with vascular dementia. This type of dementia may present with abrupt cognitive decline and stepwise deterioration. This patient has risk factors for vascular dementia such as hypertension and advanced age. However, his loss of interest, sleep disturbance, and psychomotor retardation cannot be explained by this diagnosis and warrant a different treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

A cerebral shunt is the treatment of choice for normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). While NPH typically manifests with impaired memory, other typical findings such as incontinence and ataxic gait are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

E) INCORRECT:

Memantine can be used in addition to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors in patients with moderate to severe Alzheimer dementia or vascular dementia. This patient's memory deficits could be explained by either of these dementia types, and depressive symptoms may occur in early dementia. However, his cognitive deficits are more likely to be caused by pseudodementia.
questions.hint: This patient's cognitive deficits are likely caused by pseudodementia.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of forgetfulness, difficulty concentrating, and a 4-kg weight loss. He no longer finds enjoyment in activities he once loved, seldom leaves his home, and admits to feelings of guilt and hopelessness. On examination, he is oriented to person and place but becomes tearful when asked to recall recent events. He appears reluctant to attempt memory tasks, stating that he doubts he can succeed.
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) involves measurable cognitive deficits without significant daily functioning interference. While forgetfulness and concentration issues are present, significant affective symptoms like sadness, guilt, hopelessness, anhedonia, and social withdrawal are atypical for MCI. The patient's reluctance in memory tasks and emotional distress suggest mood-related cognitive performance impact rather than primary neurocognitive disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Delirium is characterized by acute onset, fluctuating course, and disturbances in attention and consciousness. The patient's gradual symptom development over two months, stable orientation, and persistent depressive mood indicate a chronic mood-related process rather than an acute confusional state. The absence of disorganized thinking or perceptual disturbances further reduces the likelihood of delirium.

C) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease typically manifests with gradual onset and progressive memory and cognitive decline over years. The patient's short symptom duration (2 months) contrasts with Alzheimer disease's slow progression. Additionally, marked depressive features, such as anhedonia, guilt, hopelessness, and reluctance in memory tasks, suggest cognitive difficulties linked to affective disturbance rather than neurodegeneration.

D) CORRECT:

In elderly patients, major depression can manifest with cognitive complaints that resemble neurodegenerative disorders. Symptoms include forgetfulness, difficulty concentrating, anhedonia, significant weight loss, and feelings of guilt and hopelessness. Emotional lability during cognitive tasks, such as tearfulness, reflects affective disturbances in depression, contributing to cognitive impairment. This interplay between mood symptoms and cognitive dysfunction is known as depressive pseudodementia, where cognitive deficits are secondary to mood disorder rather than primary cognitive decline. This presentation, especially in older adults, necessitates a diagnostic approach considering both psychological and neurocognitive elements in major depression.

Key learning point: Depression in elderly patients can present with weight loss, loss of interest in activities, mood changes, and cognitive impairment, often referred to as 'pseudodementia.'

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man presents with progressive memory impairment for 1 year, with difficulty in planning and organization. He has a 20-year history of hypertension and a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. On examination, he is alert but frequently loses track while counting backward from 50. Neurologic examination reveals slowed gait and mild hyperreflexia. He denies hallucinations or prominent changes in behavior. All other labs are normal (see lab result and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Glucose, random
7.2 mmol/L
3.9 - 5.5 mmol/L


MRI of the brain: Diffuse periventricular white-matter hyperintensities
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s cognitive impairment?

choices.text: Subcortical small-vessel ischemic changes causing vascular cognitive impairment
Accumulation of beta-amyloid plaques leading to Alzheimer disease
Alpha-synuclein neuronal inclusions consistent with Lewy body dementia
Frontotemporal cortical atrophy characteristic of frontotemporal dementia

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient's history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus increases the risk for small-vessel disease, leading to chronic ischemic injury in the subcortical white matter. This injury disrupts frontal-subcortical circuits, causing memory impairment and executive dysfunction. The slowed gait aligns with subcortical involvement, affecting motor coordination. MRI findings of diffuse periventricular white-matter hyperintensities indicate demyelination and gliosis from chronic ischemia, linking vascular risk factors, clinical symptoms, and radiologic evidence to vascular cognitive impairment.

Key learning point: Vascular cognitive impairment is characterized by executive function impairment and MRI findings of diffuse periventricular white-matter hyperintensities, often associated with small vessel disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease is associated with beta-amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, leading to episodic memory deficits and temporoparietal cortical atrophy. The patient's symptoms, including executive dysfunction and slowed gait, along with MRI findings of white-matter hyperintensities, suggest a vascular process rather than Alzheimer disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Lewy body dementia is characterized by fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonian features. The patient lacks these symptoms and presents with executive dysfunction and vascular risk factors. MRI findings of periventricular white-matter hyperintensities support a vascular etiology rather than alpha-synuclein deposition.

D) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia typically presents with behavioral changes and language deficits, not isolated memory impairment and executive dysfunction. Imaging usually shows focal cortical atrophy, not diffuse periventricular white-matter hyperintensities. The patient's age and vascular risk factors suggest a vascular cause rather than frontotemporal dementia.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his spouse due to occasional forgetfulness of recent conversations and scheduled events over the past year, requiring reminders from family. He remains independent in shopping, cooking, and finances without notable difficulties. He is otherwise healthy. Neurological examination is normal, and there are no apparent changes in mood. Testing with a memory assessment tool shows mild deficits.
Which of the following diagnoses best explains his cognitive changes?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) is characterized by measurable memory deficits on objective testing while maintaining the ability to perform daily activities. This patient exhibits mild memory decline, such as forgetfulness of recent conversations, but remains independent in complex tasks like shopping and managing finances. MCI involves subjective or informant-reported memory complaints, objective cognitive impairment, and preserved daily functioning, all of which are present in this patient.

Key learning point: Mild cognitive impairment is characterized by objective evidence of memory decline without significant interference in daily activities.

B) INCORRECT:

Late-life depression can present with cognitive complaints, but typically includes mood disturbances like low mood and anhedonia. This patient shows mild forgetfulness without mood changes or functional impairments, making late-life depression unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease involves progressive decline in multiple cognitive domains and noticeable difficulties in daily activities. This patient has mild memory deficits but maintains independence in complex tasks, with no neurological or mood changes, which is inconsistent with Alzheimer disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Normal aging may involve minor memory lapses, but these do not typically result in measurable deficits on cognitive assessments. This patient has mild deficits on a memory assessment tool and a progressive decline noted by his spouse, indicating changes beyond normal aging.

questions.text: You are seeing an 82-year-old woman who is brought to your clinic by her son due to concerns about her forgetfulness over the past 2 years. She reports occasionally walking into a room and forgetting why she went there, often misplacing her keys, and sometimes being unable to recall the name of a familiar person. She lives independently, does her own shopping and cooking, and plays bridge with friends every weekend. Her hypertension is managed with hydrochlorothiazide. On examination, her gait is normal. She describes her mood as “good,” her thought process is organized, and her judgment is intact. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) presents with changes in personality and behavior (e.g., apathy), especially inappropriate social behavior in early stages (e.g., disinhibition), which this 82-year-old woman does not show. Additionally, the onset of FTD usually occurs in middle-aged individuals (40–60 years).

B) INCORRECT:

The degree of cognitive decline in normal pressure hydrocephalus is generally more severe than the minor memory loss seen in this patient. Normal pressure hydrocephalus presents with the classic triad of “wet, wobbly, and wacky” (urinary incontinence, gait disorder, and dementia), which this patient lacks.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with Alzheimer disease present with progressive cognitive decline that can manifest with short term memory loss. Often, patients are unaware of their difficulties and relatives may express concern before the patient does. While this patient's son does express concern over her memory loss, her daily life is largely unaffected. Moreover, the cognitive dysfunction in Alzheimer disease is often accompanied by behavioral changes (such as aggression, depression, insomnia), which are absent in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Mild memory impairment, occasional difficulties in word finding, and slower cognitive processing are normal effects of aging. An important distinguishing factor between normal aging and forms of dementia is the degree to which independence with everyday activities is impaired. In normal aging, independence in daily activities is preserved. Because this patient lives independently and her cognitive exams are within normal limits, dementia is unlikely.

Key learning point: Mild forgetfulness and slower cognitive processing with preserved daily functioning are normal effects of aging, not indicative of dementia.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with vascular dementia will present with a stepwise decline in cognitive and neurological function causing interference with independence in everyday activities. This patient has a risk factor for cerebrovascular disease (hypertension), but the minor memory loss in this patient is not consistent with the degree of cognitive impairment seen in vascular dementia. Moreover, cognitive impairment is often associated with other focal neurological deficits (e.g., hemiparesis, urinary incontinence, gait disturbance), which are absent in this patient.
questions.hint: These cognitive defects have not interfered with independence in everyday activities of this individual's life.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter after a fall at home. Over the past year, her daughter has noted increasing forgetfulness and difficulty managing finances. She also says her mother repeatedly asks her the same questions. The patient now needs reminders for meals and personal hygiene. She is alert but disoriented to date and unable to recall three objects after five minutes. Gait is mildly unsteady. Examination shows no focal neurological deficits. Vital signs are BP, 132/76; P, 78; R, 18; T, 36.9°C (98.4°F). Complete blood count, electrolytes, glucose, and thyroid-stimulating hormone are within normal limits. Noncontrast CT of the head shows diffuse cortical atrophy. Which of the following best explains this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Amnestic disorder due to head trauma

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Major neurocognitive disorder is defined by a significant decline in one or more cognitive domains that interferes with independence in daily life. This patient demonstrates marked memory loss, disorientation, and loss of functional capacity. Diffuse cortical atrophy on CT supports this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Delirium can cause confusion, disorientation, and impaired memory in older adults. However, delirium has an acute onset with fluctuating attention and consciousness, and is typically secondary to a trigger (e.g., infection, metabolic abnormality). This patient’s progressive decline over a longer period and the absence of an acute precipitant are not consistent with delirium.

C) INCORRECT:

Vascular dementia can cause cognitive impairment and gait abnormalities. However, it commonly manifests with focal neurological deficits, and imaging shows infarction or small-vessel disease. The absence of these findings makes vascular dementia less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) can cause cognitive impairment and gait disturbance. However, NPH typically also causes urinary incontinence, and imaging in NPH shows ventriculomegaly without or out of proportion to sulcal enlargement, making this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Head trauma can cause significant short-term memory loss. This patient's cognitive decline has progressed over a longer period of time and was present before her recent fall, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her son due to a 3-week history of difficulty completing household tasks and forgetting appointments. She reports that these problems began after her sister's death. During the interview, she frequently responds “I don't know” to cognitive questions and appears tearful. She mentions sleeping poorly and having little appetite. Her son says she has been avoiding social activities since the loss. Vital signs are normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This presentation is consistent with pseudodementia, which is seen in older adults with depressive disorders. Key features include sudden onset after a bereavement, the ability to recall the exact onset of symptoms, frequently responding to questions with “I don't know,” depressed mood, and social withdrawal.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause cognitive impairment, but the acute onset following bereavement with depressive symptoms makes pseudodementia more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can cause cognitive impairment and depression, but the acute onset following bereavement with depressive symptoms makes pseudodementia more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Brain MRI can identify reversible or structural causes of dementia, but the acute onset following bereavement with depressive symptoms makes pseudodementia more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

A comprehensive metabolic panel can be used to evaluate for kidney disease, liver disease, hypoglycemia, and hyperglycemia, but the acute onset following bereavement with depressive symptoms makes pseudodementia more likely.
